title.children: This former pro basketballer is using his sport to help mentor and inspire at-risk kids

image.altText: A blonde woman stands next to a smashed window

items.synopsis: Nicole's mother Galit was the only Australian to be killed by Hamas on October 7. Now she has returned to the kibbutz where she was murdered. WARNING: Some readers might find the details and images in this story distressing.

title.children: Seconds before Hamas murdered her, Galit called her daughter to deliver a final message

title.children: Chinese influence and bids for Pacific power don't mix, as Albanese is finding out

image.altText: Snake in a bucket.

title.children: Desert fires push snakes into town after generous wet seasons, plenty of mice, and 'double clutching'

image.altText: A close up of a sleeping baby with hair as a woman's hand with a gold ring touches the baby's nose.

items.synopsis: New mothers in Australia are expected to be back on their feet quickly after giving  birth. But in many ancient cultures, the first weeks are a precious time to recover and bond with the baby.

title.children: 'Many hands to hold a baby': According to Indian tradition the first 40 days after giving birth are time to heal and recover

image.altText: A photo of a woman wearing a blue shirt looking seriously off-camera. She has short, dark hair.

title.children: Embattled Aboriginal law firm NAAJA loses third chief executive in 12 months

image.altText: A man leading a buffalo off a truck

items.synopsis: Indian buffalo meat is surging into Australian market strongholds such as Indonesia, creating enormous competition for the live cattle trade.

title.children: How a stampede of Indian buffalo meat is hurting Australia's cattle trade

image.altText: Robert 'Bob' East, pictured in a motorised wheelchair

items.synopsis: Bob East died two days after his electric scooter crashed down an embankment at night. A Tasmanian coroner says he'd still be alive if a wheelchair-accessible taxi hadn't taken so long to turn up.

title.children: Man died trying to make it home himself after giving up waiting for a wheelchair taxi

items.synopsis: The UN's Special Rapporteur on occupied Palestinian territories, Francesca Albanese, says Israel cannot use the right of self defence in their bombardment of Gaza. their Follow live.

title.children: UN rapporteur says Israel does not have right to wage war under international laws

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Following up on Ms Albanese's National Press Club address, we're also hearing from foreign correspondent Nicole Johnston. Johnston lived in Gaza for a number of years as well as reporting on the conflict. She says Ms Albanese's address was "the kind of address we don't here in Australia very often". Johnston says this is the first time she's heard the international community discuss international law to this extent. "Part of the reason for that, of course, is the extraordinary number of Palestinians killed according to the Palestinian health officials as we just heard," she says. "The issue of proportionality and international law has become incredibly important." Johnston also believes one of the reasons journalists are struggling to verify information is because Israel has closed the borders into Gaza. "Israel is not allowing journalists to be in Gaza and report on this conflict," she says. "It is also, of course, a war of propaganda on both sides. "For example, the number of people killed has been a really interesting one. "We had the US and Israel come out, cast doubt on the numbers that were coming out of the Hamas-controlled health ministry. "We had Human Rights Watch and other international organisations come out and say in previous wars the numbers have been on track."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Issue of proportionality 'incredibly important' in Israel-Gaza war

children.content: Following up on Ms Albanese's National Press Club address, we're also hearing from foreign correspondent
Nicole Johnston.
Johnston lived in Gaza for a number of years as well as reporting on the conflict.
She says Ms Albanese's address was "the kind of address we don't here in Australia very often".
Johnston says this is the first time she's heard the international community discuss international law to this extent.
"Part of the reason for that, of course, is the extraordinary number of Palestinians killed according to the Palestinian health officials as we just heard," she says.
"The issue of proportionality and international law has become incredibly important."

props.alt: Woman in cream suit sits in ABC studio

children.content: Nicole Johnston says journalists are having issues verifying information in war since being blocked out from Gaza.
(ABC News )
Johnston also believes one of the reasons journalists are struggling to verify information is because Israel has closed the borders into Gaza.
"Israel is not allowing journalists to be in Gaza and report on this conflict," she says.
"It is also, of course, a war of propaganda on both sides.
"For example, the number of people killed has been a really interesting one.
"We had the US and Israel come out, cast doubt on the numbers that were coming out of the Hamas-controlled health ministry.
"We had Human Rights Watch and other international organisations come out and say in previous wars the numbers have been on track."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A humanisation of Palestinians is lacking in the coverage of the Israel-Gaza war, says Ms Albanese. "If I had to point to one thing in particular, avoid dehumanising the Palestinians, because there is a lot of this," she says. "It is across the globe. "There is a tendency to talk of Palestinian death as a tragedy while Israeli deaths as crimes. "There is a lot of empathy and solidarity that goes to the Israelis when they are a victim of violence and rightly so. "But then this is lacking on the side of the Palestinians. "As I said, they are killed, they are blamed and they are also smeared when they try to speak out."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Media needs to humanise Palestinians when reporting on conflict: UN Rapporteur

children.content: A humanisation of Palestinians is lacking in the coverage of the Israel-Gaza war, says Ms Albanese.
"If I had to point to one thing in particular, avoid dehumanising the Palestinians, because there is a lot of this," she says.
"It is across the globe.
"There is a tendency to talk of Palestinian death as a tragedy while Israeli deaths as crimes.
"There is a lot of empathy and solidarity that goes to the Israelis when they are a victim of violence and rightly so.
"But then this is lacking on the side of the Palestinians.
"As I said, they are killed, they are blamed and they are also smeared when they try to speak out."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel doesn't have the right to wage war under international laws, Ms Albanese says. She says the right of self defence can be invoked when a state is threatened by another state, which Ms Albanese claims is not what happened during the October 7 terrorist attack by Hamas. "It has been threatened by an armed group, qualify the way you want, but it is an armed group within the Occupied Territory,' she says, when asked what action Israel had the right to take. "Israel cannot claim the right of self-defence against a threat that emanates from the territory it occupies."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel doesn't have the right to wage war under international laws: UN Rapporteur

children.content: Israel doesn't have the right to wage war under international laws, Ms Albanese says.
She says the right of self defence can be invoked when a state is threatened by another state, which Ms Albanese claims is not what happened during the October 7 terrorist attack by Hamas.
"It has been threatened by an armed group, qualify the way you want, but it is an armed group within the Occupied Territory,' she says, when asked what action Israel had the right to take.
"Israel cannot claim the right of self-defence against a threat that emanates from the territory it occupies."

image.altText: Close up of red and green numbers on ASX board

items.synopsis: The Australian share market has risen moderately despite Wall Street's struggle to find direction overnight as investors await crucial inflation data that will decide how high US interest rates will climb. Follow live.

title.children: ASX rises, CBA reports $2.5b quarterly profit, Wall Street fluctuates ahead of US inflation data

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has rebounded in broad-based buying on Tuesday. Energy and mining stocks are leading the gains on the back of strong underlying commodity prices, while Commonwealth Bank rose after posting forecast-beating quarterly results. The ASX 200 index was up 0.6% to 6,991 points, after a two-session slide (and posted its biggest intraday percentage gain since November 3) Investors across the globe awaited US inflation data due out on Wednesday morning (AEDT) to gauge the monetary policy trajectory of the Federal Reserve. In Australia, energy stocks rose 2.4% after eight straight sessions of losses, and were set to climb the most since October 18, if gains hold. The sub-index received a boost from an overnight jump in oil prices as worries eased about falling demand in major oil importers like the United States and China. Beach Energy and Paladin Energy jumped 2.8% and 5.4%, respectively, to lead gains on the sub-index. Mining stocks rose 1.6%, tracking gains in iron ore prices amid optimism over stimulus measures for China's steel-heavy property sector. The sub-index was on course to gain the most in three weeks. Rio Tinto and BHP rose by 1.4% and 1.3% respectively. Shares of CBA lifted 0.6% after its first-quarter cash earnings beat market expectations. National Australia Bank slumped 3.1% in ex-dividend trading. Basically, if you didn't own shares in NAB before today, you won't receive its next dividend. Among individual stocks, ALS jumped 6.8% to become the top gainer in the benchmark index, as the business support firm posted steady half-year revenue and forecast margin improvement for its businesses in the second half of the 2023-24 financial year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX rises on broad-based gains, Commonwealth Bank inches higher

children.content: The Australian share market has rebounded in broad-based buying on Tuesday.
Energy and mining stocks are leading the gains on the back of strong underlying commodity prices, while Commonwealth Bank rose after posting forecast-beating quarterly results.
The ASX 200 index was up 0.6% to 6,991 points, after a two-session slide (and posted its biggest intraday percentage gain since November 3)
Investors across the globe awaited US inflation data due out on Wednesday morning (AEDT) to gauge the monetary policy trajectory of the Federal Reserve.
In Australia, energy stocks rose 2.4% after eight straight sessions of losses, and were set to climb the most since October 18, if gains hold.
The sub-index received a boost from an overnight jump in oil prices as worries eased about falling demand in major oil importers like the United States and China.
Beach Energy and Paladin Energy jumped 2.8% and 5.4%, respectively, to lead gains on the sub-index.
Mining stocks rose 1.6%, tracking gains in iron ore prices amid optimism over stimulus measures for China's steel-heavy property sector. The sub-index was on course to gain the most in three weeks.
Rio Tinto and BHP rose by 1.4% and 1.3% respectively.
Shares of CBA lifted 0.6% after its first-quarter cash earnings beat market expectations.
National Australia Bank slumped 3.1% in ex-dividend trading. Basically, if you didn't own shares in NAB before today, you won't receive its next dividend.

Among individual stocks, ALS jumped 6.8% to become the top gainer in the benchmark index, as the business support firm posted steady half-year revenue and forecast margin improvement for its businesses in the second half of the 2023-24 financial year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian consumers have been feeling more pessimistic after last week's interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank. Consumer sentiment fell 2.6% to a reading of 79.9 points in November, according to the latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute report. That score is consistent with the lows seen during the global financial crisis and the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. Also, any score below 100 points means the pessimists outweigh the optimists. "The RBA's November rate hike has put renewed pressure on family finances and reignited concerns about both the rising cost of living and the prospect of further rate rises to come," said Westpac senior economist Matthew Hassan. "Previous months had been showing some tentative signs that sentiment was starting to lift out of the deep pessimism that has prevailed since the middle of last year. "That rally looks to have been cut short before it even really began. "Consumers remain wary of the potential for more rises." He also said: "The weak November sentiment print is an ominous sign heading into the Christmas high season. "Pessimism is having a major bearing on spending attitudes. "Our November surveys include an additional question about Christmas spending intentions, asking consumers whether they plan to spend less, the same or more on gifts than last year. "Responses point to another 'penny-pinching' Christmas this year with nearly 40% of consumers planning to spend less on gifts."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence sinks to GFC and COVID lows

children.content: Australian consumers have been feeling more pessimistic after last week's interest rate hike by the Reserve Bank.
Consumer sentiment fell 2.6% to a reading of 79.9 points in November,
according to the latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute report.
That score is consistent with the lows seen during the global financial crisis and the height of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Also, any score below 100 points means the pessimists outweigh the optimists.

"The RBA's November rate hike has put renewed pressure on family finances and reignited concerns about both the rising cost of living and the prospect of further rate rises to come," said Westpac senior economist Matthew Hassan.
"Previous months had been showing some tentative signs that sentiment was starting to lift out of the deep pessimism that has prevailed since the middle of last year.
"That rally looks to have been cut short before it even really began.
"Consumers remain wary of the potential for more rises."
He also said: "The weak November sentiment print is an ominous sign heading into the Christmas high season.
"Pessimism is having a major bearing on spending attitudes.
"Our November surveys include an additional question about Christmas spending intentions, asking consumers whether they plan to spend less, the same or more on gifts than last year.
"Responses point to another 'penny-pinching' Christmas this year with nearly 40% of consumers planning to spend less on gifts."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Commonwealth Bank has reported that its September-quarter cash earnings were steady, and pointed to higher interest rates as the reason for a slowdown in growth and consumer spending. The country's biggest lender said its quarterly cash net profit after tax was $2.5 billion (same as the year before). A string of rate hikes since last year have boosted interest incomes and margins at Australian banks as they charged more on customer loans. But rising cost of repayments has intensified competition in the mortgage market, capping profit margins and hindering credit growth. CBA's home loan balances declined $4.5 billion in the quarter. "This reflects a disciplined approach to pricing which ensures marginal shareholder returns remain above the cost of capital in a highly competitive market," the lender said in a statement. Net interest margin was lower in the quarter, mainly due to continued competitive pressure in deposits and customers switching to higher yielding deposits, CBA added. Its common equity tier 1 ratio, a measure of spare cash, stood at 11.8% as of September-end.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA reports $2.5 billion quarterly profit

children.content: Commonwealth Bank has reported that its September-quarter cash earnings were steady, and pointed to higher interest rates as the reason for a slowdown in growth and consumer spending.
The country's biggest lender said its quarterly cash net profit after tax was
$2.5 billion
(same as the year before).
A string of rate hikes since last year have boosted interest incomes and margins at Australian banks as they charged more on customer loans.
But rising cost of repayments has intensified competition in the mortgage market, capping profit margins and hindering credit growth.
CBA's home loan balances declined $4.5 billion in the quarter.
"This reflects a disciplined approach to pricing which ensures marginal shareholder returns remain above the cost of capital in a highly competitive market," the lender said in a statement.
Net interest margin was lower in the quarter, mainly due to continued competitive pressure in deposits and customers switching to higher yielding deposits, CBA added.
Its common equity tier 1 ratio, a measure of spare cash, stood at 11.8% as of September-end.
